Problem:
Consider the interaction between two functions defined over scalar fields, \\( u(z) = e^{az} \\) and \\( v(z) = e^{bz} \\), where a and b are constants, in the context of an integro-differential equation \\( \\frac{d}{dz} \\left( h(z) \\right) = \\int_0^z u(\\tau) v(z - \\tau) d\\tau \\).

If the initial condition \\( h(0) = h_0 \\) is set and the system is allowed to evolve without further intervention, will the solution \\( h(z) \\) solely depend on the parameters a and b of the functions u and v?
Explanation: The solution \\( h(z) \\) of the integro-differential equation is defined by the convolution of \\( u(z) \\) and \\( v(z) \\) and the initial condition \\( h_0 \\). It inherently depends only on the parameters a and b through the defined convolution, without involvement of any other external parameters or modifications.
